articles.title: Boyne Resorts Announces Launch Of The Boyne Forever Foundation
articles.content: Boyne Resorts, North America's largest family-owned four-season resort company, today announced the launch of the Boyne Forever Foundation, an independent 501(c)(3) public charity. This strategic philanthropic initiative will work in partnership with all 13 Boyne Resorts properties to amplify their collective impact and create greater year-over-year support for local and national causes. The Foundation represents a historic milestone for the company, channeling nearly 80 years of community commitment into one focused effort driven by the core principles that have defined the Boyne Resorts family since 1948. As an independent public charity, the Boyne Forever Foundation (BFF) will focus its efforts on three priorities that reflect the heart of Boyne Resorts' identity: investing in the communities where resorts are located, caring for the people who bring these resorts to life, and protecting the environment. articles.title: Swiss-Ski And Snowboard Community Mourning The Loss Of Ueli Kestenholz.
articles.content: Swiss-Ski and the snowboard community are mourning the loss of Ueli Kestenholz. The first Swiss Olympic medalist in a snowboard discipline died in an avalanche at the young age of 50. Ueli Kestenholz made a name for himself as a competitive athlete, a name that still resonates 20 years after the end of this chapter. In 1998, the then 22-year-old from Thun suddenly found himself in the spotlight: When snowboarders participated in the Winter Olympics for the first time in Nagano, Ueli won a medal for Switzerland in the first snowboard event in Olympic history: bronze in the parallel giant slalom Ueli's journey in snow sports began with skiing; he was even a member of a ski club when he discovered snowboarding at the age of 14. "I skateboarded, I was a windsurfer, but I only skied in the winter, and on two planks," Ueli Kestenholz explained in a Tamedia interview two years ago. It hopes incoming storms allow a quick return. The independent ski area , located in McCloud, announced the closure as unseasonably warm and dry conditions have left the resort with only 79 inches of snow this season. The resort opened on December 27 and has received no new snow in February. General Manager Brendan Hickey addressed the closure in a video message, standing at the base of muddy slopes. He confirmed that incoming weather systems are forecast to bring snow to the region. The ski park hopes to reopen by Friday, February 13, following big snow from the forecasted storm system. articles.title: Historic Washington Ski Area Needs Help To Survive
articles.description: The Washington ski area is raising money to pay for future insurance dues and to replace its broken snow groomer.
articles.content: Waterville, Washington — One of the most historic ski areas in the West has yet to operate this winter. Badger Mountain is among the most notable mom-and-pop operations in the Pacific Northwest, with very affordable lift tickets. However, it has limited operations because it relies on natural snowfall. Currently, they need help on two major projects. The non-profit that runs the ski area currently has minimal (if any) money in its bank account, and bills are due. They need to keep the power on and pay for insurance, which costs $350 a month. Their snow groomer is also broken, but they’re being offered a used snow groomer. You can help them out by sending a check to HighLine Grain Growers, C/O Paul Katovich, PO Box 649, Waterville, WA, 98858. Alternatively, you ca n Venmo them (@badgermtski). articles.title: Another Oregon Ski Resort Temporarily Pauses Operations
articles.description: While an Oregon ski resort shut down operations on Saturday, recent snowfall and a change in the forecast will help them out.
articles.content: Oregon — Oregon’s rough ski season is expected to take a turn in the right direction this week, but not before another ski resort paused its operations. On Saturday, Willamette Pass announced that its pausing operations following a heavy rain event on February 8th. Like the rest of Oregon’s ski industry, it’s been dealing with spring conditions and a diminishing snowpack. As of Saturday, Willamette Pass has only recieved 36″ of natural snow, and snowmaking has only helped so much. When they were open, it was only on a limited amount of terrain. View this post on Instagram Luckily, the past 24 hours have brought snow back to the ski resort. We’ll see how long their closure takes, but it won’t likely be long. Willamette Pass joins Hoodoo Ski Area, Mt. Ashland, and Mt. Hood Skibowl as Oregon ski areas/resorts that have temporarily suspended operations. articles.title: Snowboarder Falls Into Hidden Ravine @ Canadian Ski Resort
articles.description: These snowboarders were riding at a resort in British Columbia when the lead boarder fell into a hidden ravine complete with a small stream.
articles.content: Skiing or snowboarding off-trail, whether it’s inbounds or backcountry, can come with unexpected hazards. These snowboarders were riding at Revelstoke Mountain Resort in British Columbia when the lead boarder fell into a hidden ravine complete with a small stream. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Jérémie Allaire (@t.ijay_) It seems like the ravine was covered in snow right up until the lead boarder ran over it causing the snow to collapse. Fortunately it wasn’t that deep and the guy seemed just fine despite the fall. Nonetheless, this video serves as a reminder to ski or ride with a buddy if you’re going to head off trail. No doubt the climb out of the ravine was a battle, and if he was alone and had fallen into something deeper or something without much of an exit path, it could have been a long time before anyone found him. articles.title: Notorious Quebec Ski Resort Announces Start Of Capital Improvement Projects
articles.description: After a bumpy start to the 2025-26 season, a Quebec ski resort has announced major on-mountain improvements.
articles.content: Quebec — Well, here are some words I never thought I would type out: Resorts of the Canadian Rockies (RCR) is spending lots of money on one of its properties. Yesterday, Mont-Sainte-Anne and the Quebec government announced a relaunch of their partnership, with an investment of $100 million CAD (nearly $72.4 million) to revitalize one of Quebec’s largest ski resorts. These projects are funded partly by RCR, with the other funds coming from two loans provided by the province. The plan is now in the implementation stage. “We were able to cross the finish line by establishing a true partnership with Investissement Québec and SÉPAQ, enabling the rapid injection of $100 million into the ski mountain’s infrastructure and tourism offering to ensure its modernization. Significant efforts were made by all parties to ensure the long-term coherence and sustainability of the destination through a renewed approach,” said Maxime Cretin, the Vice President and General Manager of RCR’s Eastern Region.

For hundreds of years, the residents of northern Scandinavia have used reindeer to pull them for travel on skis in difficult arctic terrain. Even older claims of humans being pulled by dogs with ski-like foot coverings have emerged from the Altai Mountains in Central Asia. This was not for sport, but out of necessity for travel purposes. The name “Skijoring” is derived from the Norwegian translation for “Ski Driving.” Snow stacks up in Silverton, Colorado, as the course gets spicier by the minute. articles.content: Fortress Mountain’s front runs and abandoned facilities are waiting for redevelopment. – Photo Credit: Black Crows Fortress Mountain is located about an hour southwest of Calgary, Alberta. The base of the resort is situated on top of a flat ridge at 6,700 feet. From the old base lodge, you have a 360-degree view of the surrounding mountain peaks above and the Kananaskis Valley below. Thanks to the elevation, Fortress Mountain receives generous amounts of low-density snow averaging 300 inches annually. The resort operated for the first time in 1967 under the name Snow Ridge. Unfortunately, the resort didn’t have much success in the first few seasons due to the long unpaved road to the resort. The Canadian government did eventually agree to pave 30 of the 36 miles of road but gave no timeframe for when it would get done. articles.content: 21-Year-Old Skier Dies After Leaving the Piste in Courmayeur A tragic ski accident has claimed the life of a 21-year-old skier in Courmayeur , in Italy’s Aosta Valley , after he left a marked piste and collided with a tree. According to reporting by Corriere Torino , the young skier was descending a return run in the Dolonne area of the Courmayeur ski domain when he lost control, exited the piste and struck a tree at high speed. The impact was fatal, and the skier died at the scene. Emergency services, including piste patrol, local police and the Aosta Valley Mountain Rescue Service, were immediately dispatched. Despite rapid intervention, there was nothing rescuers could do to save him. Authorities carried out the necessary procedures to recover the body and investigate the circumstances of the accident. articles.content: TL;DR – Read This First The 2025–26 winter season has seen unusually unstable snowpacks across both the Alps and North America. Despite repeated avalanche warnings from ski patrols, mountain guides and rescue services, many skiers and snowboarders continue to go off-piste during high-risk periods — sometimes ignoring advice, challenging warnings, or reacting aggressively when asked to turn back. When accidents happen, the same professionals who tried to prevent these decisions are forced to carry out complex and dangerous rescue operations , often in extremely unstable terrain. Respecting avalanche bulletins and closures doesn’t just protect skiers — it protects the rescuers who put their lives at risk to save others. Photo: Herbert Maeder. Wikipedia Commons. articles.content: Val Thorens winter driving rules have been tightened in the Belleville Valley, covering Val Thorens, Les Menuires and Saint-Martin-de-Belleville. These Val Thorens winter driving measures apply throughout the entire ski season. A new municipal decree confirms that vehicles must be equipped with either four winter tyres in good condition or snow chains . Snow socks and all-season tyres are explicitly not considered adequate equipment. For a full breakdown of winter tyre and snow chain rules across the Alps and Europe — including what’s accepted where and why — see our guide to winter tyres and snow chains . These Val Thorens winter driving rules are enforced throughout the Belleville Valley ski season. Under Article 4.2 of the decree, law enforcement may deny access to the resorts if vehicles are fitted with snow socks that are not suitable for heavily snow-covered or icy roads. articles.content: Why Skiing Alone Is Dangerous in the Mountains Skiing alone is often seen as peaceful, efficient or even safer — fewer people, fewer variables, fewer mistakes. For experienced skiers in particular, solo skiing can feel controlled and familiar. In reality, skiing alone is one of the strongest risk factors in fatal mountain accidents , whether caused by avalanches, collisions, falls or medical emergencies. This article explains why skiing alone dramatically increases danger , even for skilled and cautious skiers. The Most Critical Factor: No Immediate Help When skiing alone, there is no margin for error . In many mountain accidents: The victim is unable to call for help Injuries prevent movement or communication Time becomes the decisive factor In avalanches, survival often depends on rescue within minutes . articles.title: PlanetSKI Heads Out with the Glenshee Ski Patrol

articles.content: Despite over 20 years of skiing, I’ve never been the most technical or agile person on the slopes. But that’s not the reason I find myself wrapped around a fence halfway down a green run at Glenshee Ski Centre on a Saturday afternoon in January. It is, thankfully, a training exercise that myself and others are taking part in. PlanetSKI with the Glenshee Ski Patrol. Image © Julia Clarke/PlanetSKI I’m here in the Scottish Highlands to shadow two days of training with the British Association of Ski Patrollers, BASP, and it’s my turn to be the casualty. Under the guidance of BASP president Gerard “Gerry” Cameron, I’ve skied about halfway down Claybokie, positioned myself as though my day has ended with a yard sale, and am now awaiting rescue from two men who are going through today’s training.
